-C Tools

-C1 Federated Learning

Federated Learning (FL) enables n𝑛n clients to train a global model w collaboratively without revealing local datasets. Unlike centralized learning, FL requires clients to upload the weights of local models ({wi∣i∈n}conditional-setsuperscriptw𝑖𝑖𝑛\{\textit{{w}}^{i}\mid i\in n\}) to a parametric server. It aims to optimize a loss function: arg⁡minw∑i=1nkiK​ℒi​(w,𝒟i),subscriptwsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑘𝑖𝐾subscriptℒ𝑖wsubscript𝒟𝑖\mathop{\arg\min}\limits_{\textit{{w}}}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{\frac{{{k_{i}}}}{K}{\mathcal{L}_{i}}(}\textit{{w}},\mathcal{D}_{i}), where ℒi​(⋅)subscriptℒ𝑖⋅{\mathcal{L}_{i}}(\cdot) and kisubscript𝑘𝑖k_{i} are the loss function and local data size of i𝑖i-th client. At t𝑡t-th round, the training of FL can usually be divided into the following steps.
∙∙\bullet Global model download: The server selects partial clients engaging in training. All connected clients download the global model wt−1subscriptw𝑡1\textit{{w}}_{t-1} from the server.
∙∙\bullet Local training: Each client updates its local model by training with its own dataset: gt−1i←∂ℒ​(wt−1,𝒟i)∂wt−1←superscriptsubscriptg𝑡1𝑖ℒsubscriptw𝑡1subscript𝒟𝑖subscriptw𝑡1\textit{{g}}_{t-1}^{i}\leftarrow\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}(\textit{{w}}_{t-1},\mathcal{D}_{i})}{\partial\textit{{w}}_{t-1}}.
∙∙\bullet Aggregation: After the local updates {gt−1i∣i∈n}conditional-setsubscriptsuperscriptg𝑖𝑡1𝑖𝑛\{\textit{{g}}^{i}_{t-1}\mid i\in n\} are uploaded, the server updates the global model by aggregation: wt←wt−1−η​∑i=1nkiK​gt−1i←subscriptw𝑡subscriptw𝑡1𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑘𝑖𝐾superscriptsubscriptg𝑡1𝑖\textit{{w}}_{t}\leftarrow\textit{{w}}_{t-1}-\eta\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\frac{{{k_{i}}}}{K}\textit{{g}}_{t-1}^{i}, where η𝜂\eta refers to the learning rate.

-C2 DBSCAN

Unlike traditional clustering algorithms (e.g., k-means, k-means++, bi-kmeans), which need to pre-define the number of clusters, Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN) [24] is proposed to cluster data points dynamically. Based on density-based clustering, DBSCAN guarantees that clusters of any shape can always be identified. Besides, it can recognize noise points effectively. Basically, after setting the density parameter (α𝛼\alpha) and the minimum cluster size (m​P​t​s𝑚𝑃𝑡𝑠mPts), DBSCAN can conduct effective clustering. We note HDBSCAN [13] could be also used for clustering. Its main difference from DBSCAN is the multiple densities clustering. In this work, we assume that malicious clients may only conduct one kind of attack during the whole training, e.g., a group of malicious clients conducting a Label Flipping Attack together. The malicious updates could only derive one density. Like [49], we may apply HDBSCAN in the clustering. But DBSCAN, in general, requires less computational complexity than HDBSCAN in algorithmic constructions. And further, we will conduct the clustering with cryptographic operations. Considering efficiency, we choose DBSCAN over HDBSCAN.

-C3 Cryptographic Tools

The secure Multiparty Computation (MPC) framework aims to enable multiple parties to evaluate a function over ciphertexts securely. The parties conducting MPC can access inputs via protection approaches, e.g., in a secret-shared format. It does not leak any information besides the final output unless these shares are combined to derive plaintexts.

Secret Sharing (SS). It refers to a type of tool for splitting a secret among multiple parties, each of whom is assigned a share of the secret. The security of an SS scheme guarantees that one can distinguish shares and randoms with a negligible probability. Apart from that, no one can reconstruct the secret unless holding all (or a subset) of shares. Let us consider Shamir Secret Sharing (SSS) [56] (t,n)𝑡𝑛(t,n)-threshold scheme as an example. Assume one chooses a polynomial f​(x)=∑i=0t−1ai⋅xi𝑓𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑡1⋅subscript𝑎𝑖superscript𝑥𝑖f(x)=\sum_{i=0}^{t-1}a_{i}\cdot x^{i} over ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{q} and a secret a0=f​(0)subscript𝑎0𝑓0a_{0}=f(0). The secret can be split into n𝑛n shares by randomly selecting n𝑛n values: {rj←ℤq∗∣j∈n}conditional-set←subscript𝑟𝑗superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑗𝑛\{r_{j}\leftarrow\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{*}\mid j\in n\}, and then calculating shares {f​(rj)∣j∈n}conditional-set𝑓subscript𝑟𝑗𝑗𝑛\{f(r_{j})\mid j\in n\}. Given a subset of any t𝑡t out of n𝑛n shares, the secret can by reconstructed by Lagrange interpolation [7]:f​(0)=∑j=0t−1f​(rj)⋅∏z=0,z≠jt−1rzrz−rj𝑓0superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑡1⋅𝑓subscript𝑟𝑗superscriptsubscriptproductformulae-sequence𝑧0𝑧𝑗𝑡1subscript𝑟𝑧subscript𝑟𝑧subscript𝑟𝑗f(0)=\sum_{j=0}^{t-1}f(r_{j})\cdot\prod_{z=0,z\neq j}^{t-1}\frac{r_{z}}{r_{z}-r_{j}}. Except for SSS, other schemes like additive SS and replicated SS are used in the MPC framework [33, 18]. Note these schemes have a linear property. Even if each party performs linear combinations locally with shares, the combined secret matches the result obtained by these linear calculations. This saves significant communication costs in the FL context, where servers are only required to aggregate shares of gradients.
Homomorphic Hash Functions (HHF). Given a message x∈ℤq𝑥subscriptℤ𝑞x\in\mathbb{Z}_{q}, a collision-resistant HHF [26] \hash: 𝔾1×𝔾2←ℤq←subscript𝔾1subscript𝔾2subscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{G}_{1}\times\mathbb{G}_{2}\leftarrow\mathbb{Z}_{q} can be indicated as \hash​(x)=(g\hashδ,ϕ′​(x),h\hashδ,ϕ′​(x))\hash𝑥superscript𝑔subscriptsuperscript\hash′𝛿italic-ϕ𝑥superscriptℎsubscriptsuperscript\hash′𝛿italic-ϕ𝑥\hash(x)=(g^{\hash^{{}^{\prime}}_{\delta,\phi}(x)},h^{\hash^{{}^{\prime}}_{\delta,\phi}(x)}), where δ𝛿\delta and ϕitalic-ϕ\phi are secret keys randomly and independently selected from ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{q}. \hash′superscript\hash′\hash^{{}^{\prime}} is a hash function, and 𝔾1subscript𝔾1\mathbb{G}_{1} and 𝔾2subscript𝔾2\mathbb{G}_{2} are two different groups. Similar to other one-way hash functions, the security of the HHF requires that one can find a collision with a negligible probability. Based on additive homomorphism: \hash​(x1+x2)←(g\hashδ,ϕ′​(x1)+\hashδ,ϕ′​(x2),h\hashδ,ϕ′​(x1)+\hashδ,ϕ′​(x2))←\hashsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2superscript𝑔subscriptsuperscript\hash′𝛿italic-ϕsubscript𝑥1subscriptsuperscript\hash′𝛿italic-ϕsubscript𝑥2superscriptℎsubscriptsuperscript\hash′𝛿italic-ϕsubscript𝑥1subscriptsuperscript\hash′𝛿italic-ϕsubscript𝑥2\hash(x_{1}+x_{2})\leftarrow(g^{\hash^{{}^{\prime}}_{\delta,\phi}(x_{1})+\hash^{{}^{\prime}}_{\delta,\phi}(x_{2})},h^{\hash^{{}^{\prime}}_{\delta,\phi}(x_{1})+\hash^{{}^{\prime}}_{\delta,\phi}(x_{2})}), in this work, we will use this tool as a verification of the correctness of aggregation.

Homomorphic Encryption (HE). This tool is an interesting privacy-preserving technology enabling users to evaluate polynomial computations on ciphertexts without revealing underlying plaintexts. An encryption scheme is called partial HE if it only supports addition [50] or multiplication [23], while fully HE [29] can support both. An HE scheme usually includes the following steps.
∙∙\bullet Key Generation: (\pk,\sk)\pk\sk(\pk,\sk) ←\kgen←absent\kgen\leftarrow\kgen (1λsuperscript1𝜆1^{\lambda}), where based on security level parameter λ𝜆\lambda, public key \pk\pk\pk and secret key \sk\sk\sk can be generated.
∙∙\bullet Encryption: (c1,c2)←\enc​(\pk,m1,m2)←subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2\enc\pksubscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2(c_{1},c_{2})\leftarrow\enc(\pk,m_{1},m_{2}). By using \pk\pk\pk, the probabilistic algorithm encrypts messages m1,m2subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2m_{1},m_{2} to ciphertexts c1,c2subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2c_{1},c_{2}.
∙∙\bullet Homomorphic evaluation: \eval​(c1,c2)=c1∘c2=\enc​(\pk,m1)∘\enc​(\pk,m2)=\enc​(\pk,m1∘m2)\evalsubscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2\enc\pksubscript𝑚1\enc\pksubscript𝑚2\enc\pksubscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2\eval(c_{1},c_{2})=c_{1}\circ c_{2}=\enc(\pk,m_{1})\circ\enc(\pk,m_{2})=\enc(\pk,m_{1}\circ m_{2}), where ∘\circ refers to an operator, e.g., addition or multiplication.
∙∙\bullet Decryption: m1∘m2←\dec​(\sk,\enc​(\pk,m1∘m2))←subscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2\dec\sk\enc\pksubscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2m_{1}\circ m_{2}\leftarrow\dec(\sk,\enc(\pk,m_{1}\circ m_{2})). Using \sk\sk\sk, the operational results of m1subscript𝑚1m_{1} and m2subscript𝑚2m_{2} can be derived.

Oblivious Transfer (OT). OT [52] is one of the crucial building blocks for MPC. In an OT protocol (involving two parties), a sender holds n𝑛n different strings si,i=1​⋯​n,subscript𝑠𝑖𝑖1⋯𝑛s_{i},i=1\cdots n, and a receiver has an index (i​n​d𝑖𝑛𝑑ind) and wants to learn si​n​dsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑛𝑑s_{ind}. At the end of the protocol, the receiver cannot get information about strings rather than si​n​dsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑛𝑑s_{ind}, while the sender learns nothing about i​n​d𝑖𝑛𝑑ind selected by the receiver. For example, a 1-out-of-2 OT protocol only inputs two strings and a 1-bit index.

Garbled Circuits (GC) [5]. The protocol is run between two parties called the garbler and evaluator. The garbler generates the GC corresponding to the Boolean circuit to be evaluated securely by associating two random keys per wire representing the bit values 0, 1. The garbler then sends the GC together with the keys for the inputs to the evaluator. The evaluator obliviously obtains the keys for his inputs via OT and evaluates the circuit to obtain the output key. Finally, the evaluator maps the output key to the real output.

-C4 Differential Privacy

Differential Privacy (DP) [22] is a data protection approach enabling one to publish statistical information of datasets while keeping individual data private. The security of DP requires that adversaries cannot statistically distinguish the changes between two datasets where an arbitrary data point is different. The most widely used DP mechanism is called (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP defined below, requiring less injection noise than the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP but standing at the same privacy level.

Definition 1 ((ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta) - Differential Privacy [22]).

Given two real positive numbers (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta) and a randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}: 𝒟n→𝒴→superscript𝒟𝑛𝒴\mathcal{D}^{n}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y}, the algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} provides (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta) - DP if for all data sets 𝐃,𝐃′∈𝒟n𝐃superscript𝐃′superscript𝒟𝑛\mathbf{D},\mathbf{D}^{{}^{\prime}}\in\mathcal{D}^{n} differing in only one data sample, and all 𝒮⊆𝒴𝒮𝒴\mathcal{S}\subseteq\mathcal{Y}: P​r​[𝒜​(𝐃)∈𝒮]≤e​x​p​(ϵ)⋅P​r​[𝒜​(𝐃′)∈𝒮]+δ.𝑃𝑟delimited-[]𝒜𝐃𝒮⋅𝑒𝑥𝑝italic-ϵ𝑃𝑟delimited-[]𝒜superscript𝐃′𝒮𝛿Pr[\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{D})\in\mathcal{S}]\leq exp(\epsilon)\cdot Pr[\mathcal{A}(\mathbf{D}^{{}^{\prime}})\in\mathcal{S}]+\delta.

Note that the Gaussian noise 𝒩∼N​(0,Δ2​σ2)similar-to𝒩𝑁0superscriptΔ2superscript𝜎2\mathcal{N}\sim N(0,\Delta^{2}\sigma^{2}) should be added to the output of the algorithm, where ΔΔ\Delta is L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} sensitivity of 𝐃𝐃\mathbf{D} and σ𝜎\sigma=2​ln⁡(1.25/δ)21.25𝛿\sqrt{2\ln(1.25/\delta)} [1]. The robustness of post-processing guarantees for any probabilistic/deterministic functions ℱℱ\mathcal{F}, if 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP, so does ℱ​(𝒜)ℱ𝒜\mathcal{F(A)}.

-D Complexity Analysis

We use d𝑑d to denote the dimension of the model. n𝑛n, S𝑆S and c𝑐c refer to the number of clients, servers and clusters, respectively.
∙∙\bullet Computation cost. Each client’s computation cost can be computed as binary SS with Tiny OT −- O​(d)𝑂𝑑O(d). The server’s computation cost consists of 4 parts: (1) computing pairwise XOR −- O​(n2)𝑂superscript𝑛2O(n^{2}); (2) bit to arithmetic conversion −- O​(d)𝑂𝑑O(d); (3) multiplication for L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} distance −- O​(n3)𝑂superscript𝑛3O(n^{3}); (4) comparison with α𝛼\alpha −- O​(n2)𝑂superscript𝑛2O(n^{2}); (5) calculating results of HHF based on the number of clusters c𝑐c −- O​(n​c)𝑂𝑛𝑐O(nc). Thus, the total computation complexity of each server is O​(n3)𝑂superscript𝑛3O(n^{3}).
∙∙\bullet Communication cost. For a client in MUDGUARD, the communication cost can be divided into 2 parts: (1) sending updates to S𝑆S servers with binary SS and Tiny OT −- O​(S​d)𝑂𝑆𝑑O(Sd); (2) broadcasting hash results of updates to the rest of parties −- O​(n+S)𝑂𝑛𝑆O(n+S). Thus, we have communication complexity −- O​(S​d+n)𝑂𝑆𝑑𝑛O(Sd+n) for each client. The servers’ communication costs include (1) receiving correlated randomness and doubly-authenticated bits for converting a boolean shared matrix to arithmetic one −- O​(n2)𝑂superscript𝑛2O(n^{2}); (2) receiving triples for multiplications −- O​(n2)𝑂superscript𝑛2O(n^{2}); (3) receiving correlated randomness for element-wise comparison −- O​(n2)𝑂superscript𝑛2O(n^{2}); (4) sending shares and a random bit to other servers for reconstruction −- O​(S​n2)𝑂𝑆superscript𝑛2O(Sn^{2}); (5) sending aggregated shares and values of HHF to all clients −- O​(n​d)𝑂𝑛𝑑O(nd). Overall, the communication cost for every server is O​(S​n2)𝑂𝑆superscript𝑛2O(Sn^{2}). For detailed experimental results, refer to Section V-B.

-E Security Analysis

We first define the ideal functionality ℱMUDGUARDsubscriptℱMUDGUARD\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{MUDGUARD}} to execute a byzantine-robust privacy-preserving FL, and then show that the proposed protocol ΠMUDGUARDsubscriptΠMUDGUARD\Pi_{\textsf{MUDGUARD}} securely realizes the functionality. Our security is based on the random oracle model where the homomorphic hash function outputs a uniformly random value for a new query and the same value for a previously answered query, hence we prove the UC security in ℱROsubscriptℱRO\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{RO}}-hybrid model. Besides, the security is also based on the existence of a secret sharing protocol where the clients derive shares indistinguishable with randoms which securely realizes ℱSSsubscriptℱSS\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{SS}} (a combination of ℱtriples,ℱshare,ℱreconstsubscriptℱtriplessubscriptℱsharesubscriptℱreconst\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{triples}},\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{share}},\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{reconst}} [27]), and a bit-to-arithmetic conversion protocol that securely realizes ℱB2AsubscriptℱB2A\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{B2A}} (noted as ℱPREPsubscriptℱPREP\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{PREP}} in [54]).

Ideal Functionality ℱsharesubscriptℱshare\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{share}}

The functionality ℱsharesubscriptℱshare\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{share}} interacts with a dealer party PjsubscriptP𝑗\textsf{P}_{j}, and a corrupted party PisubscriptP𝑖\textsf{P}_{i}.

Upon receiving (ti,si)subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑠𝑖(t_{i},s_{i}) from the corrupted party PisubscriptP𝑖\textsf{P}_{i}, and receiving v𝑣v from the dealer PjsubscriptP𝑗\textsf{P}_{j}, the functionality ℱsharesubscriptℱshare\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{share}} computes (tj+1,sj+1)subscript𝑡𝑗1subscript𝑠𝑗1(t_{j+1},s_{j+1}) and (tj+2,sj+2)subscript𝑡𝑗2subscript𝑠𝑗2(t_{j+2},s_{j+2}) from (ti,si)subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑠𝑖(t_{i},s_{i}) and v𝑣v, and sends the honest Pi−1subscriptP𝑖1\textsf{P}_{i-1} and Pi+1subscriptP𝑖1\textsf{P}_{i+1} their respective shares.

Remark.

We use ℱsharesubscriptℱshare\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{share}} as the secret share generating algorithm, ℱreconstsubscriptℱreconst\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{reconst}} as the reconstructing algorithm, ℱtriplessubscriptℱtriples\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{triples}} as the secret share multiplication algorithm, and ℱB2AsubscriptℱB2A\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{B2A}} (see ℱPREPsubscriptℱPREP\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{PREP}} in [54]) as the bit to arithmetic conversion algorithm.

Remark.

According to the ideal functionality, we could capture not only privacy but also soundness against malicious corruption of servers. However, the differential attack is based on the output of each epoch, which is published roundly and could be obtained legally. Hence, the discussion on differential privacy is not included in this security definition. Detailed proof for differential privacy will be given later. Moreover, soundness against malicious corruption of clients is also not captured by the previous definition since such security is protected by the clustering technique, which is not the concern of cryptography.

Definition 2 (Universally Composable security).

A protocol ΠΠ\Pi UC-realizes ideal functionality ℱℱ\mathcal{F} if for any PPT adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} there exists a PPT simulator 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} such that, for any PPT environment ℰℰ\mathcal{E}, the ensembles 𝖤𝖷𝖤𝖢Π,𝒜,ℰsubscript𝖤𝖷𝖤𝖢Π𝒜ℰ\mathsf{EXEC}_{\Pi,\mathcal{A},\mathcal{E}} and 𝖤𝖷𝖤𝖢𝖨𝖣𝖤𝖠𝖫ℱ,𝒮,ℰsubscript𝖤𝖷𝖤𝖢subscript𝖨𝖣𝖤𝖠𝖫ℱ𝒮ℰ\mathsf{EXEC}_{\mathsf{IDEAL}_{\mathcal{F}},\mathcal{S},\mathcal{E}} are indistinguishable.

Definition 3 (UC security of MUDGUARD).

A protocol ΠMUDGUARDsubscriptΠMUDGUARD\Pi_{\textsf{{MUDGUARD}}} is UC-secure if ΠMUDGUARDsubscriptΠMUDGUARD\Pi_{\textsf{{MUDGUARD}}} UC-realizes ℱℱ\mathcal{F}, against malicious-majority clients and malicious-minority servers, considering arbitrary collusion between malicious parties.

Theorem 3 (UC security of MUDGUARD).

Suppose the existence of a homomorphic hash function in a random oracle model, our protocol is UC-secure in (ℱRO,ℱSS,ℱB2A)subscriptℱROsubscriptℱSSsubscriptℱB2A(\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{RO}},\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{SS}},\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{B2A}})-hybrid world.

Proof.

We show the validity of the theorem by proving that the protocol ΠMUDGUARDsubscriptΠMUDGUARD\Pi_{\textsf{{MUDGUARD}}} securely realizes ℱℱ\mathcal{F} in the (ℱRO,ℱSS,ℱB2A)subscriptℱROsubscriptℱSSsubscriptℱB2A(\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{RO}},\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{SS}},\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{B2A}})-hybrid world against any corruption pattern. We construct a simulator Sim for any non-uniform PPT environment ℰℰ\mathcal{E} such that EXECΠMUDGUARD,𝒜,ℰℱRO,ℱSS,ℱB2A≈EXECℱMUDGUARD,Sim,𝒵superscriptsubscriptEXECsubscriptΠMUDGUARD𝒜ℰsubscriptℱROsubscriptℱSSsubscriptℱB2AsubscriptEXECsubscriptℱMUDGUARDSim𝒵\textsf{EXEC}_{\Pi_{\textsf{{MUDGUARD}}},\mathcal{A},\mathcal{E}}^{\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{RO}},\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{SS}},\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{B2A}}}\approx\textsf{EXEC}_{\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{{MUDGUARD}}},\textsf{Sim},\mathcal{Z}}. The Sim is constructed as follows.

It writes on 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}’s input tape upon receiving an input value from ℰℰ\mathcal{E}, as if coming from ℰℰ\mathcal{E}, and writes on 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}’s output tape upon receiving an output value from 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, as if from 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}.

Case 1: If all clients and servers are not corrupted. Since we assume private channels between client and server, Sim could just simply randomly choose all intermediate values. There is no distinguisher who could tell the difference between random values and real transcripts.

Case 2: If corrupted clients exist. We note the corrupted subset as ℐ⊂[n]ℐdelimited-[]𝑛\mathcal{I}\subset[n]. We need to simulate the adversary’s view, which is the secret share and its corresponding hash value. For t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T] and i∈ℐ𝑖ℐi\in\mathcal{I}, the simulator randomly chosen g′¯ti←{0,1}←superscriptsubscript¯superscriptg′𝑡𝑖01\bar{\textit{{g}}^{\prime}}_{t}^{i}\leftarrow\{0,1\}, and internally executes ℱSSsubscriptℱSS\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{SS}} to obtain [[g′¯ti]]delimited-[]delimited-[]superscriptsubscript¯superscriptg′𝑡𝑖[\![\bar{\textit{{g}}^{\prime}}_{t}^{i}]\!]. Then, Sim internally executes ℱROsubscriptℱRO\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{RO}} to obtain \hashtisuperscriptsubscript\hash𝑡𝑖\hash_{t}^{i}. Because of the UC security of ℱSSsubscriptℱSS\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{SS}} and ℱROsubscriptℱRO\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{RO}}, there is no distinguisher that could tell the difference between ([[g′¯ti]],\hashti)delimited-[]delimited-[]superscriptsubscript¯superscriptg′𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript\hash𝑡𝑖([\![\bar{\textit{{g}}^{\prime}}_{t}^{i}]\!],\hash_{t}^{i}) and ([[g¯ti]],Hδ,ϕ​(sign​(g^ti)))delimited-[]delimited-[]superscriptsubscript¯g𝑡𝑖subscriptH𝛿italic-ϕsignsuperscriptsubscript^𝑔𝑡𝑖([\![\bar{\textit{{g}}}_{t}^{i}]\!],\textsf{H}_{\delta,\phi}(\textsf{sign}(\hat{g}_{t}^{i}))).

Case 3: If corrupted servers exist. We not the corrupted subset as ℐ⊂[T]ℐdelimited-[]𝑇\mathcal{I}\subset[T]. We need to simulate the adversary’s view, including all secret shares in the protocol. It is worth noticing that we should not only guarantee the indistinguishability between two groups of shares but also the relationship among elements within each group. After obtaining IndM, the Sim executes DBSCAN protocol on IndM and acquires cluster labels l𝑙l, and executes the functionality ℱSSsubscriptℱSS\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{SS}} to obtain [[IndMi​j]]delimited-[]delimited-[]subscriptIndM𝑖𝑗[\![\textsf{IndM}_{ij}]\!] for each i,j∈[n]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑛i,j\in[n]. Then, Sim randomly chosen |l|𝑙|l| secret sharing values [[g′¯ti]]delimited-[]delimited-[]superscriptsubscript¯superscriptg′𝑡𝑖[\![\bar{\textit{{g}}^{\prime}}_{t}^{i}]\!] such that the summation Σli=z​DCD​([[g′¯ti]])subscriptΣsubscript𝑙𝑖𝑧DCDdelimited-[]delimited-[]superscriptsubscript¯superscriptg′𝑡𝑖\Sigma_{l_{i}=z}\textsf{DCD}([\![\bar{\textit{{g}}^{\prime}}_{t}^{i}]\!]) equals to the given share [[Gtz]]delimited-[]delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptG𝑡𝑧[\![\textit{{G}}_{t}^{z}]\!]. This procedure could be easily achieved by first randomly choosing the first |l|−1𝑙1|l|-1 values and then calculating the last value. For each i∉c𝑖𝑐i\notin c, the simulator Sim simply chooses the shares of gradients randomly since those values are irrelevant to the calculation. After acquiring all the shares of gradients [[g′¯ti]]delimited-[]delimited-[]superscriptsubscript¯superscriptg′𝑡𝑖[\![\bar{\textit{{g}}^{\prime}}_{t}^{i}]\!], the simulation Sim pairwisely calculate [[d​o​t​_​p​r​o​d​u​c​ti​j′]]delimited-[]delimited-[]𝑑𝑜𝑡_𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑑𝑢𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑡′𝑖𝑗[\![dot\_product^{\prime}_{ij}]\!], and convert it to arithmetic sharing by executing the functionality ℱB2AsubscriptℱB2A\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{B2A}}, and then calculate the adjusted cosine similarity matrix share [[CosMi​j′]]delimited-[]delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptCosM′𝑖𝑗[\![\textsf{CosM}^{\prime}_{ij}]\!]. Next, as in Algorithm 2, Sim calculates [[xi​j′]],[[EucMi​j′]]delimited-[]delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝑥′𝑖𝑗delimited-[]delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptEucM′𝑖𝑗[\![x^{\prime}_{ij}]\!],[\![\textsf{EucM}^{\prime}_{ij}]\!] for each i,j∈[n]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑛i,j\in[n]. We claim that all shares that were previously generated are interdeducible, except between [[EucMi​j′]]delimited-[]delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptEucM′𝑖𝑗[\![\textsf{EucM}^{\prime}_{ij}]\!] and [[IndMi​j′]]delimited-[]delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptIndM′𝑖𝑗[\![\textsf{IndM}^{\prime}_{ij}]\!], since the latter two are the input/output pair of the element-wise comparison algorithm computed by a secure comparison algorithm in our protocol. Fortunately, the privacy of a secure comparison algorithm guarantees the indistinguishability between real and ideal input/output pairs. Hence, we claim that if there exists a distinguisher that could tell the difference between the real and ideal world, it contradicts either the UC security of ℱSSsubscriptℱSS\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{SS}} or the privacy of secure comparison protocol.

Case 4: If there exists both corrupted clients and servers. The situation, in this case, is simply the combination of Case 2 and 3 since there is no extra view needed to simulate.

In summary, for any PPT adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} we could construct a Sim, so that for any PPT environment ℰℰ\mathcal{E}, the 𝖤𝖷𝖤𝖢Π,𝒜,ℰsubscript𝖤𝖷𝖤𝖢Π𝒜ℰ\mathsf{EXEC}_{\Pi,\mathcal{A},\mathcal{E}} and 𝖤𝖷𝖤𝖢ℱMUDGUARD,𝒮,ℰsubscript𝖤𝖷𝖤𝖢subscriptℱMUDGUARD𝒮ℰ\mathsf{EXEC}_{{\mathcal{F}_{\textsf{{MUDGUARD}}}},\mathcal{S},\mathcal{E}} are indistinguishable. ∎

UC framework captures attacks on input and intermediate data. On the contrary, differential privacy prevents the adversary from inferring about private information from outputs or updates, and such information might also be utilized by malicious clients. When false positives clustering exists, or malicious clients pretend to be honest, local updates have a chance to be revealed to the adversary. The following theorem shows that these updates do not leak any individual data due to differential privacy.

Theorem 4.

No adversary in corrupted client set \advc⊂𝒞superscript\adv𝑐𝒞\adv^{c}\subset\mathcal{C}, where |\advc|≤n−1superscript\adv𝑐𝑛1|\adv^{c}|\leq n-1, can retrieve the individual values of honest clients.

Proof.

Since we apply differential privacy [22], the local updates cannot leak information regarding the inputs. According to Def. 1, the added differentially private noise guarantees that the aggregation is indistinguishable whether an individual update participates or not. Therefore, it guarantees the security of individual local updates while aggregation can be calculated. ∎

-F Convergence Analysis

Let M𝑀M be the total number of clients in a semi-honest majority client cluster. Semi-honest clients and malicious clients are indexed by {1,⋯,h}1⋯ℎ\{1,\cdots,h\} and {h+1,⋯,h+m}ℎ1⋯ℎ𝑚\{h+1,\cdots,h+m\}, respectively, where M=h+m𝑀ℎ𝑚M=h+m and h>mℎ𝑚h>m if TNR is greater than 50%. The component j𝑗j of stochastic gradient and of true gradient are denoted as {g~i,j}i=1Msuperscriptsubscriptsubscript~𝑔𝑖𝑗𝑖1𝑀\{\tilde{g}_{i,j}\}_{i=1}^{M} and gjsubscript𝑔𝑗g_{j} respectively. An error probability is shown as follows.

Lemma 1 (The bound of error probability with malicious clients).

If the TNR (h/M) of the clustering is relatively high, then we have the error probability ℙ​[\sign​[∑i=1M\sign​(g~i,j)]≠\sign​(gj)]≤ℙh⋅𝒪​(M/h)ℙdelimited-[]\signdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀\signsubscript~𝑔𝑖𝑗\signsubscript𝑔𝑗⋅subscriptℙℎ𝒪𝑀ℎ\mathbb{P}\left[\sign\left[\sum_{i=1}^{M}\sign(\tilde{g}_{i,j})\right]\not=\sign(g_{j})\right]\leq\mathbb{P}_{h}\cdot\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{M/h}), where ℙhsubscriptℙℎ\mathbb{P}_{h} is the bound for the error probability without malicious clients.

Proof.

Every client is a Bernoulli trial with success probability phsubscript𝑝ℎp_{h} for semi-honest clients and pmsubscript𝑝𝑚p_{m} for malicious clients, respectively, to receive the true gradient signs. Let Zhsubscript𝑍ℎZ_{h} be the number of semi-honest clients with true signs, which therefore equals the sum of hℎh independent Bernoulli trials, so we know Zhsubscript𝑍ℎZ_{h} follows the binomial distribution B​(h,ph)𝐵ℎsubscript𝑝ℎB(h,p_{h}). Similarly, we know the number of malicious clients with correct signs Zmsubscript𝑍𝑚Z_{m} follows the binomial distribution B​(m,pm)𝐵𝑚subscript𝑝𝑚B(m,p_{m}). Denote qh=1−phsubscript𝑞ℎ1subscript𝑝ℎq_{h}=1-p_{h} and qm=1−pmsubscript𝑞𝑚1subscript𝑝𝑚q_{m}=1-p_{m}.

Let Z𝑍Z be the total number of clients with true gradient signs, so Z=Zh+Zm𝑍subscript𝑍ℎsubscript𝑍𝑚Z=Z_{h}+Z_{m}. We use the Gaussian distribution to simplify the analysis. Notice that B​(h,ph)∼N​(h​ph,h​ph​qh)similar-to𝐵ℎsubscript𝑝ℎ𝑁ℎsubscript𝑝ℎℎsubscript𝑝ℎsubscript𝑞ℎB(h,p_{h})\sim N(hp_{h},hp_{h}q_{h}) and B​(m,pm)∼N​(m​pm,m​pm​qm)similar-to𝐵𝑚subscript𝑝𝑚𝑁𝑚subscript𝑝𝑚𝑚subscript𝑝𝑚subscript𝑞𝑚B(m,p_{m})\sim N(mp_{m},mp_{m}q_{m}), so we get Z∼N​(h​ph+m​pm,h​ph​qh+m​pm​qm).similar-to𝑍𝑁ℎsubscript𝑝ℎ𝑚subscript𝑝𝑚ℎsubscript𝑝ℎsubscript𝑞ℎ𝑚subscript𝑝𝑚subscript𝑞𝑚Z\sim N\left(hp_{h}+mp_{m},hp_{h}q_{h}+mp_{m}q_{m}\right). The event \sign​[∑i=1M\sign​(g~i,j)]≠\sign​(gj)\signdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀\signsubscript~𝑔𝑖𝑗\signsubscript𝑔𝑗\sign\left[\sum_{i=1}^{M}\sign(\tilde{g}_{i,j})\right]\not=\sign(g_{j}) is equivalent to event Z≤M/2𝑍𝑀2Z\leq M/2. Then the error probability equals ℙ​(Z≤M/2)ℙ𝑍𝑀2\mathbb{P}(Z\leq M/2). By using Cantelli’s inequality, we know

The first factor in Eq. (1) is the bound for the error probability without malicious clients, so we get the error probability less than a 𝒪​(M/h)𝒪𝑀ℎ\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{M/h}) factor of that in the case of without malicious clients. ∎

Let L and 𝝈𝝈\bm{\sigma} be non-negative losses and standard deviation of stochastic gradients g~~𝑔\tilde{g} respectively. ∀xfor-all𝑥\forall x, the objective values f​(x)𝑓𝑥f(x) are bounded by constants f∗subscript𝑓f_{*} (i.e. f​(x)≥f∗𝑓𝑥subscript𝑓f(x)\geq f_{*}). The objective value of 0-t​h𝑡ℎth round is referred to as f0subscript𝑓0f_{0}. Under the above conditions, the results are the following.

Theorem 5 (Non-convex convergence rate of MUDGUARD).

If the TNR of the clustering is relatively high, then the global model generated in the semi-honest cluster converges at a rate

𝔼​[1T​∑t=0T−1‖gt‖1]2≤𝔼superscriptdelimited-[]1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscriptnormsubscript𝑔𝑡12absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\left\|g_{t}\right\|_{1}\right]^{2}\leq 1N[‖L‖1(f0−f∗+12)\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\Bigg{[}\sqrt{\|\textbf{L}\|_{1}}\left(f_{0}-f_{*}+\frac{1}{2}\right)
+2𝒪​(h)∥𝝈∥1]2,\displaystyle+\frac{2}{\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{h})}\|\bm{\sigma}\|_{1}\Bigg{]}^{2},

where N𝑁N is the cumulative number of stochastic gradient calls up to round T (i.e.,N=𝒪(T2))(i.e.,N=\mathcal{O}(T^{2})). Therefore, the higher the rate is, the closer the convergence speed is to the case without malicious clients.

Proof.

Following the results of Theorem 2 in [6], in the distributed SignSGD with a majority vote, we can get the non-convex convergence rate without malicious clients at

𝔼​[1T​∑t=0T−1‖gt‖1]2≤𝔼superscriptdelimited-[]1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscriptnormsubscript𝑔𝑡12absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\left\|g_{t}\right\|_{1}\right]^{2}\leq 1N[‖L‖1(f0−f∗+12)\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\Bigg{[}\sqrt{\|\textbf{L}\|_{1}}\left(f_{0}-f_{*}+\frac{1}{2}\right) (2)
+2M∥𝝈∥1]2\displaystyle+\frac{2}{\sqrt{M}}\|\bm{\sigma}\|_{1}\Bigg{]}^{2}

from

|gt|​ℙ​[\sign​[∑i=1M\sign​(g~i,j)]≠\sign​(gj)]≤σiM.subscript𝑔𝑡ℙdelimited-[]\signdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀\signsubscript~𝑔𝑖𝑗\signsubscript𝑔𝑗subscript𝜎𝑖𝑀\displaystyle|g_{t}|\mathbb{P}\left[\sign\left[\sum_{i=1}^{M}\sign(\tilde{g}_{i,j})\right]\not=\sign(g_{j})\right]\leq\frac{\sigma_{i}}{\sqrt{M}}. (3)

By plugging the result into (2), we have the convergence rate of MUDGUARD:

𝔼​[1T​∑t=0T−1‖gt‖1]2≤𝔼superscriptdelimited-[]1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscriptnormsubscript𝑔𝑡12absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\left\|g_{t}\right\|_{1}\right]^{2}\leq 1N[‖L‖1(f0−f∗+12)\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\Bigg{[}\sqrt{\|\textbf{L}\|_{1}}\left(f_{0}-f_{*}+\frac{1}{2}\right) (4)

+2𝒪​(h)∥𝝈∥1]2.\displaystyle+\frac{2}{\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{h})}\|\bm{\sigma}\|_{1}\Bigg{]}^{2}.

∎

-G Proof of Theorem 1

Proof.

We denote a=(a1,⋯,ad)𝑎subscript𝑎1⋯subscript𝑎𝑑a=(a_{1},\cdots,a_{d}) and b=(b1,⋯,bd)𝑏subscript𝑏1⋯subscript𝑏𝑑b=(b_{1},\cdots,b_{d}) are two vectors uploaded by malicious clients, where n​p𝑛𝑝np refers to the number of model parameters:

P​r​(ai,bi=𝗌𝗂𝗀𝗇)={12,𝗌𝗂𝗀𝗇=+112,𝗌𝗂𝗀𝗇=−1,∀i∈[d].formulae-sequence𝑃𝑟subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖𝗌𝗂𝗀𝗇cases12𝗌𝗂𝗀𝗇112𝗌𝗂𝗀𝗇1for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑑Pr(a_{i},b_{i}=\mathsf{sign})=\begin{cases}\frac{1}{2},&\mathsf{sign}=+1\\ \frac{1}{2},&\mathsf{sign}=-1\end{cases},\ \forall i\in[d].

The adjusted cosine similarity can be computed as:

C​O​S​_​s​i​m​i​l​a​r​i​t​y𝐶𝑂𝑆_𝑠𝑖𝑚𝑖𝑙𝑎𝑟𝑖𝑡𝑦\displaystyle COS\_similarity =a1​b1+⋯+ad​bda12+⋯+ad2⋅b12+⋯+bd2absentsubscript𝑎1subscript𝑏1⋯subscript𝑎𝑑subscript𝑏𝑑⋅superscriptsubscript𝑎12⋯superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑑2superscriptsubscript𝑏12⋯superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑑2\displaystyle=\frac{a_{1}b_{1}+\cdots+a_{d}b_{d}}{\sqrt{a_{1}^{2}+\cdots+a_{d}^{2}}\cdot\sqrt{b_{1}^{2}+\cdots+b_{d}^{2}}}
=a1​b1+⋯+ad​bdd.absentsubscript𝑎1subscript𝑏1⋯subscript𝑎𝑑subscript𝑏𝑑𝑑\displaystyle=\frac{a_{1}b_{1}+\cdots+a_{d}b_{d}}{d}.

Since aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i} and bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} are relatively independent, we have:

P​r​(ai⋅bi=𝗌𝗂𝗀𝗇)={12,𝗌𝗂𝗀𝗇=+112,𝗌𝗂𝗀𝗇=−1,∀i∈[d].formulae-sequence𝑃𝑟⋅subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖𝗌𝗂𝗀𝗇cases12𝗌𝗂𝗀𝗇112𝗌𝗂𝗀𝗇1for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑑Pr(a_{i}\cdot b_{i}=\mathsf{sign})=\begin{cases}\frac{1}{2},&\mathsf{sign}=+1\\ \frac{1}{2},&\mathsf{sign}=-1\end{cases},\ \forall i\in[d].

According to the Law of large numbers, E​(C​O​S​_​s​i​m​i​l​a​r​i​t​y)∼E​(ai​bi)=0.similar-to𝐸𝐶𝑂𝑆_𝑠𝑖𝑚𝑖𝑙𝑎𝑟𝑖𝑡𝑦𝐸subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖0E(COS\_similarity)\sim E(a_{i}b_{i})=0. This conclusion can be generalized to any two malicious clients, and malicious clients have the same distance as a semi-honest client. Therefore, if we calculate the adjusted cosine similarity vector of two malicious clients, there should be only two elements of difference. The L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} distance of these two vectors is 22\sqrt{2}. ∎

-H Other Experimental Setup and Experimental Results

-H1 Other Experiment Setup

We implement MUDGUARD in C++ and Python. We use MP-SPDZ library [33] to implement secure computations and Pytorch framework [51] for training. All the experiments are conducted on a cluster of machines with Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-2620 v4 @ 2.10GHz and NVIDIA 1080 Ti GPU, with 32GB RAM in a local area network. As for the cryptographic tools, all the parameters are set to a 128-bit security level.
Datasets. We use MNIST and FMNIST datasets for the image classification task.
∙∙\bullet MNIST [39]. It consists of 60,000 training samples and 10,000 testing samples, where each sample is a 28×\times28 gray-scale image of handwritten digital (0-9).
∙∙\bullet FMNIST [61]. It contains article images from Zalando and has the same size as MNIST, where each image is a 28×\times28 gray-scale image associated with a label from 10 classes.
∙∙\bullet CIFAR-10 [36]. It offers 50,000 training samples and 10,000 test samples, where each is a 32×\times32 color image in a label from 10 different objectives, and there are 6,000 images for each class.
Classifiers. We use LeNet and ResNet-18 to perform training and classification of the datasets.
∙∙\bullet LeNet [38]. Containing 6 layers (including 3 convolution layers, 2 pooling layers, and 1 fully connected layer), LeNet aims to train 44,426 parameters for image classification.
∙∙\bullet ResNet-18 [32]. It provides 18 layers with 11 million trainable parameters to train color images. We use a light vision of ResNet with approx. 2.07 million parameters and complete the experiments with the CIFAR-10 dataset.

-H2 Other Experimental Results

In Figures 4 and 5, we present the comparison of testing accuracy among baseline, semi-honest and malicious groups under targeted attacks and ASR between the groups under untargeted attacks. In addition, we also give the experimental results by varying proportion of malicious clients (ξ≥0.5𝜉0.5\xi\geq 0.5), #clients n𝑛n and non-iid degree q𝑞q in Tables VII and VIII. We see that the results are consistent with the analysis in Section V-A: the untargeted attacks nearly have no impact on the accuracy of the final model (only slightly decreasing the speed of convergence). Since GA may directly upload noise, it can be easily detected from the beginning of the training to the end, resulting in the same convergence as the baseline. For LFA, Krum, Trim, and AA Attacks, MUDGUARD is also difficult to distinguish between semi-honest and malicious clients at the beginning. Thus, the speed of convergence is slightly decreased. The main difference is that: LeNet achieves around 78%percent7878\% in FMNIST, while ResNet-18 provides approx. 56%percent5656\% accuracy in CIFAR-10.

We also provide comparisons with the state-of-the-art Byzantine-robust methods in Figure 6 and 7 on FMNIST and CIFAR-10 respectively. Similar to Figure 3, under the malicious majority of untargeted attacks, the testing accuracies of FLTrust, MUDGUARD, and weights-MUDGUARD are maintained at the same level of the baseline. Under the targeted attacks, FLTrust, MUDGUARD, and weights-MUDGUARD can restrain ASR to about 0%-10%. For more detailed explanations, please refer to Section V-A.

Impact of α𝛼\alpha on robustness of MUDGUARD Turning back to Section IV-B and Theorem 1, the Byzantine-robustness of MUDGUARD relies on whether we can choose a desirable density α𝛼\alpha. From the experimental results in Section V-A, we know that EA has a stronger stealthiness than other attacks. Therefore, we use EA as an example in this section to analyze the influence of α𝛼\alpha on MUDGUARD. Figure 8 shows how the ASR and clustering accuracy varies in semi-honest and malicious groups under EA when we change α𝛼\alpha. Consistent with Theorem 1, once α𝛼\alpha is great than 22\sqrt{2}, the malicious and semi-honest clients will cluster together, resulting in MUDGUARD loss of the effectiveness of Byzantine-robustness. A similar situation can be found when α𝛼\alpha is set as too small (in this case, all clients will be identified as noise.). From the experiment, we found 1 is a best practice for α𝛼\alpha, so we set it as the default parameter. Nevertheless, MUDGUARD cannot 100% guarantee to exclude EA because EA has a strong stealthiness. We will leave this as future work.

Impact of λ𝜆\lambda on Adaptive Attack. Figure 9 shows how the ASR varies in semi-honest and malicious groups when we adapt BA to MUDGUARD, where (F)MNIST, CIFAR-10 and default settings in Table II are used. In MNIST (Figure 9a), the ASR of the semi-honest group remains at a low level (nearly 0%) while that of the malicious group raises from 0.23 to 1 as λ𝜆\lambda grows from 0.1 to 0.3. This is so because when the value of λ𝜆\lambda is low, the malicious clients using AA more focus on evading filtering (i.e., inducing a drop in clustering accuracy). Even if malicious clients are grouped with semi-honest clients, they cannot produce practical attack effectiveness. When the value of λ𝜆\lambda gradually increases, the malicious clients will focus more on attack performance. In this way, MUDGUARD will easily distinguish the malicious from the semi-honest. It thus can resist AA. Note the experimental results with FMNIST and CIFAR-10 (Figure 9b and c) share the same trend with MNIST (Figure 9a).

-I Discussions

-I1 Boosting Accuracy

Intuitively, CIFAR-10 is more difficult to train than (F)MNIST. SignSGD [6] achieves 90% accuracy with centralized learning. The reasons for the accuracy drop in FL are (1) the number of clients: when the number increases, the amount of data allocated to a client becomes smaller, and the local model is more prone to overfitting; (2) Data heterogeneity: a larger degree of non-iid leads to less information being available for the local model to learn, which harms accuracy; (3) Malicious clients: malicious clients taking a part of the training data can be filtered out by MUDGUARD. This is equivalent to discarding that part of the training data. Additional improvements in accuracy could be obtained by using different models, e.g., ViT [21], or by performing hyperparameters grid search for FL, etc.

-I2 Comparison of Overheads with FLAME

Intuitively, systems that use clustering, like FLAME [49], could experience efficiency problem if left without proper optimization. In our design, MPC impacts three main phases: computation of 𝖢𝗈𝗌𝖬𝖢𝗈𝗌𝖬\mathsf{CosM}, L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} distance, and element-wise comparison. The 1st stage is the most computationally expensive. We, therefore, focus on its optimization. After the optimization, the servers avoid using “heavy" tools, like HE and Beaver’s multiplication, to calculate cosine so that communication and computational overheads are naturally reduced. Therefore, MUDGUARD has much lighter complexity than FLAME.

Note that FLAME uses a 2-party semi-honest MPC scheme which is very similar to the semi-honest situation in our design (Table V). Our optimized version of MUDGUARD is less computationally and communicationally complex than FLAME. In MUDGUARD, 𝖢𝗈𝗌𝖬𝖢𝗈𝗌𝖬\mathsf{CosM} is calculated by doing XOR locally on servers, and the matrix size reduces from the number of clients ×\times the number of model updates (n×d𝑛𝑑n\times d) to n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n after calculation. Then this n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n matrix is used to calculate the pairwise-L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} distance (where only multiplication is involved). In FLAME, directly calculating cosine similarity requires multiplication, division, and the square root of the n×d𝑛𝑑n\times d matrix, which are relatively intensive, expensive operations in MPC. The fact that FLAME’s code is not publicly available prevents a code/implementation-based comparison.

We followed state-of-the-art Byzantine-robust FL [15]’s default setting on the client number (number = 100). Table V shows overheads (the runtime and communication costs) on the server side are acceptable; in particular, only 0.4s and 16 MB are required with LeNet in the semi-honest case.

-I3 Defending Against Other Attacks

In the experiments, we consider SOTA (un)targeted attacks. We say that interested readers may use other attacks to test MUDGUARD, in which Byzantine-robustness could not be seriously affected. We take the Distributed Backdoor Attack (DBA) [62] as an example. DBA decomposes a global trigger into several pieces distributed to local clients. It, however, yields significant changes to some dimensions of updates to maintain the ASR of the backdoor task. Since the cosine distance between malicious and benign updates are distinguishable, MUDGUARD can still work well under DBA. Note another attack, Little Is Enough [4], have not been considered in this work because it requires attackers to have knowledge of the gradients of semi-honest clients, which violates privacy preservation.

-I4 Advantages of Adjusted Cosine Similarity

As shown in Figure 10, we present an example of the calculation of adjusted cosine similarity. It is clear to see that adjusted cosine similarity is able to capture the magnitudes and directions of updates by transferring updates to adjusted updates. Although m1subscript𝑚1m_{1} does not have too many differences in directions (i.e., m1subscript𝑚1m_{1} will be clustered with h1subscriptℎ1h_{1} and h2subscriptℎ2h_{2}), its differences with h1subscriptℎ1h_{1} and h2subscriptℎ2h_{2} in magnitudes can be easily captured by 𝖢𝗈𝗌𝖬𝖢𝗈𝗌𝖬\mathsf{CosM}. Furthermore, due to non-iid, the (h1subscriptℎ1h_{1}, h2subscriptℎ2h_{2}) and (h3subscriptℎ3h_{3}, h4subscriptℎ4h_{4}) will be clustered into two groups if cosine distance is applied. However, by subtracting mean updates, this influence can be reduced.

We also show the experimental results in Figure 11, where FMNIST is used under BA and the number of clients is set to 10 (the first six are benign clients, the rest are malicious clients). The rest of the default settings follow Table II. From Figure 10, we can see that if only cosine distance is calculated, honest updates will be classified as noise due to the influence of non-iid. The adjusted cosine similarity weakens this effect (Figure 10b). Calculating the L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} distance again will make the distinction between the two groups more obvious (Figure 10c).

Furthermore, we provide a comparison when MUDGUARD uses cosine similarity and adjusted cosine similarity for clustering in Figure 12. It is clear to see that the testing accuracy of MUDGUARD with cosine similarity abruptly goes down when the model approaches convergence. On the contrary, this does not happen in MUDGUARD with adjusted cosine similarity. The detailed explanation is given in Section IV-B.

-I5 Dynamic Attacks

Recall that MUDGUARD can perform well in terms of testing accuracy under the assumption that malicious clients consistently perform one type of attack (e.g., GA) throughout the whole training period. It can also perform well if we allow malicious clients to perform different attacks on the epochs, e.g., GA to the first 10 epochs and then Krum attacks to the remaining epochs. We notice that all the attacks (we consider in this work) except GA may require several epochs of training (as a buffer) to produce attack effects. But these buffer epochs can boost MUDGUARD’s clustering performance. This is so because the clustering ability is enhanced with the increase of training rounds. On the other hand, the TNR and TPR (of the clustering) could be relatively low in these epochs. Some malicious clients can be clustered into a semi-honest group, but this will not seriously affect the accuracy performance of the model.

One may think malicious clients are allowed to perform all the attacks in a single epoch. But so far, it is unknown how to group those attacks together friendly and meanwhile maximize their attack effects. In practice, the attacks may deliver an update in different directions, and further, they may even yield influence on each other. For example, GA could easily destroy the convergence of BA. We say that it is an interesting open problem to consider launching GA, LFA, Krum, Trim, and AA attacks together in an epoch to evaluate the accuracy and ARS.

-I6 Varying Clients Subsampling Rate

We assert that MUDGUARD can perform well under different clients’ subsampling rates. This benefits from the proposed Model Segmentation that can resist malicious-majority clients. Imagine that in the context of an honest majority (e.g., 40 out of 100 are malicious), if the subsampling rate is set relatively low (e.g., 10%), we eventually have a malicious majority case in one training epoch with a high probability. Our experimental results have demonstrated that MUDGUARD can still achieve Byzantine-robustness under a low subsampling rate.

-I7 Learning Rate and Local Epoch

They are subtle parameters that decide the performance of FL training. A low learning rate can slow down the speed of convergence, and on the other hand, a high rate hinders the model’s convergence, harming accuracy. As for the local epoch, in the case of iid, if carefully increasing the number of epochs, we can make the model converge fast. But under a large degree of non-iid (e.g., q=0.5), the increase of epoch leads to updates in different directions, making the FedAvg algorithm invalid [43]. In this work, we set these two parameters according to the recommendations given in [43, 6]. Exploring their impacts on training is orthogonal to the main focus of this work.

-I8 Privacy-preserving DBSCAN

This is one of the core parts we used to build MUDGUARD. It can apply to other real-world domains, e.g., anomaly detection and encrypted traffic analytics, where data should be clustered securely. But we note that the current MUDGUARD with optimization may not scale well in these applications. We did the optimization for the sake of efficiency by using SignSGD and binary secret sharing, which cannot support precise floating-point arithmetic.

-I9 Test Datasets

We notice that the EA is not applicable for FMINST since the research work [58] did not provide a backdoor dataset. We leave this as an open problem. Based on the performance of MUDGUARD on MNIST and CIFAR-10, we claim that even in FMNIST, the ASR of EA stays low, which is consistent with our main conclusion.

In the experiments, we conduct three image datasets (MNIST, FMNIST, and CIFAR-10). We claim that MUDGUARD can be further used to capture the Byzantine-robust and privacy-preserving features of the models trained on text and speech datasets, where the text dataset for the next-word prediction task can require Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs). To train these datasets, we can also use weights or gradients to update the models (in the context of FL). If the models or datasets are poisoned (by malicious clients), malicious updates have differences in updates directions from benign ones. Then we can use MUDGUARD to protect benign clients. We could use other types of datasets during training, but this will not affect our conclusions on Byzantine robustness and privacy preservation.

-I10 Limitations

Using weights as updates. To provide cost-effective secure computations, the proposed MUDGUARD only implements the update method by SignSGD. If we use weights as updates, the secret shares sent to the servers will be in floating-point format. In this case, we will have to downgrade the design to the unoptimized MUDGUARD in Table V, which could cause a considerable amount of both communication costs and runtime. An interesting future work could be to propose a more lightweight (than the current design) and secure MPC framework for MUDGUARD.

Performance under EA. Although MUDGUARD does achieve good performance in terms of accuracy and (to some extent) efficiency, under the EA, MUDGUARD’s ASR cannot be eventually reduced to nearly 0%. In future work, we will improve the TNR and TPR of the clustering algorithm so as to recognize subtle differences between malicious and semi-honest clients.
